Core stats knowledge needed for major, continuation of 241

On the last class, we gained a preview of the concepts taught in machine learning. This class definitely seems to set us up well for learning about neural networks and machine learning.

Knowledge of standard concepts in a mathematical statistics curriculum. Learned multiple regression, ANOVA testing, and theory behind Chi-Square testing, all of which were lacking in my prior statistics background.

theoretical ways to estimate parameters of data

How to evaluate big data sets
The syllabus is pretty self-explanatory.

Knowledge: Central limit theorem illustrated formally using moment generating functions. Key distributions such as Normal, Chi^2, t, f. Parameter estimation (method of moments, maximum likelihood, bayes priors) and their distributional properties (delta method, fischer information as estimate of asymptotic variance); test statistics. Hypothesis tests (Neyman-Pearson simple-vs-simple uniformly most powerful tests; generalized likelihood ratios and chi^2 goodness of fit test for curve fitting with a binomially distributed full model for the data); p-values. Comparing two samples (t-tests, estimates of population variance). Comparing means under various conditions using ANOVA. Linear regression of one and multiple variables to explain a dependent variables. Fuller models including interactions and neural techniques. Data transformations. Connections between regression and earlier topics.
Skills: By hand calculations of the above; some limited proof; a fair amount of R coding towards the end.
Insights: Understanding the scientific method and its limitations. Philosophical reflections on the notion of explanation, causation and their epistemic status.
Honestly, I learned a little first semester about statistics, but mostly taught to myself. Barron was a terrible lecturer.
Learning to view the world as probabilistic, definitely a helpful skill.
Know what happens behind a command you give to R
I learned lots about distributions and the theory behind statistical tests.
We talked about how to derive some of the basic stats stuff that you use pretty often.

First half of the course: parameter estimation (i.e., estimating the values of the parameters of distributions) through estimators like the MME, MLE, etc. Also Bayesian priors and posteriors. Second half of the course: statistical tests and power, linear regression, ANOVA. (Dont think the second half is a rehash of AP Stat: it goes much, much deeper than that.) We used a lot of R/Minitab in the second half. He teaches using Minitab in class, you pick R or Minitab for homework, and he said about 70% of students chose to use R.

This course primarily consists of two parts. The first half of the course covers parameter estimation, and the second half of the course covers hypothesis testing. With the first half of the course, we spent maybe at most two weeks doing review of some statistical concepts that might have been covered in an introductory statistics course and of some probability from 241. With the main content then, for the first half regarding parameter estimation, we covered the method of moments estimate (MME), maximum likelihood estimate (MLE), and Bayes estimates with prior and posterior distributions. Other important concepts with the first half were the Fisher information, bias and best unbiased in relation to variance, mean squared error (MSE), sufficiency, and asymptotic and exact distributions. Then, with the second half regarding hypothesis testing, we covered likelihood ratio tests, generalized likelihood ratio tests, Pearson's Chi-square goodness-of-fit test, z-tests, t-tests, ANOVA, and regression.

This course helped reinforce my background in statistical theory. Many of the concepts covered I had learned in previous statistics classes, but this class delved much deeper into them to show how the mathematics behind them works. Most importantly, this course teaches you how to address different kinds of statistical problems.

This course went into a lot of detail discussing the theory behind things like the method of moments, maximum likelihood estimators, and parameter estimation using bayesian techniques. The course the broadly overviewed things like regression, model fitting, etc. This is all really important info, and definitely important to know for stats, applied math, or anything in STEM.

I learned some key concepts in statistics like MLEs and other estimators for parameters, t-tests and ANOVA tests, and linear regression. The material was very theoretical and builds upon probability theory in S&DS 241. I learned how to perform these tests and with MLEs, mostly, some of the intuition and logic behind inference.

This course taught me the basics of statistical distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, and regressions. It was really helpful because it gave you the theoretical background of all of these topics. For example, I can now say exactly why the t-statistic has a t-distribution, or why maximum likelihood estimation is used to estimate parameters of probability distributions.
Theoretical foundations of statistical topics like parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, and regression.
some specific statistical theory knowledge

This is a theory based course primarily in frequentist statistics. We reviewed relevant probability theory from 241 (probability measures, important distributions, moment generating functions, etc.). Then we learned about various methods of parameter estimation (method of moments, maximum likelihood, least squares, and the Bayesian approach). The second half of the course focused on hypothesis testing (Neyman Pierson framework, likelihood ratios, generalized likelihood ratios, goodness of fit tests, comparing means in two samples (t-test) and multiple samples (ANOVA)) and regression.

Lecture was TERRIBLE. i am really sick of these math lectures where the professors dont know how to teach or explain anything.

The materials are fundamental to lots of science things, so its a must.

The class was super disorganized. Prof Barron would just write randomly all over the board in no clear pattern and it was impossible to follow what was happening and also very difficult to read his handwriting on the chalkboard. Also, it was almost impossible to get help. There was 1-hour section on Mondays which was really good but that was literally the only time you could get help for the pset due Wednesday. Strengths: the professor is very knowledgeable about statistics, and clearly cares a great deal about the subject. He is always responsive and kind in responding to student questions.
Weaknesses: although the professor has a very strong understanding of statistics himself, he struggles to convey that understanding to students. Lectures were disorganized, confusing, and hard to follow. The course did not follow the book very closely, and the book was more advanced than the class, which made it hard to use the book to supplement confusing lectures from class. After a couple weeks, the majority of people stopped attending lecture since it wasnt very helpful. The professor frequently veered off into topics beyond the scope of the course, at the expense of teaching material that we needed to learn and that people did not understand. The course could be improved by any, but preferably all, of the following: 1) select a new textbook at a more appropriate level for the class, 2) have the lecture more closely track the textbook, 3) do not spend so much class time discussing material beyond the scope of the course, 4) teach the material in a clearer and more understandable way, 5) do not assign problem sets due the week of exams or the week after spring break.

I really enjoyed this course in that, in having this course now under my belt, I feel so much more integrated in the statistical community, even if just at the beginning stages so far. I feel like I'm starting to understand some of the concepts overall, even though there is definitely room for improvement. I think the strengths of this course were the office hours with the people. I think that talking one-on-one with the professor is extremely helpful; Professor Barron is very knowledgeable and explains concepts at your pace if you talk with him during office hours. Just from lecture, it feels like the material goes above your head, but when you meet with the professor, you get to ask questions at your pace, and Professor Barron is really, really good at picking out what you don't understand or just explaining it more clearly. The same goes for the TFs. The TFs for this course were incredibly helpful, and their discussion sessions were really helpful with getting through the class. It would have been awesome if they could have had office hours or if there had just been more opportunities to talk to them. And the ULAs were incredible too. I just want to give a shout-out to Katherine Brumberg who is the best ULA. She is incredible; she was so, so helpful with going through concepts and making things more understandable. If we could get more help, I feel like I would have been able to leave this class with a much more thorough understanding of the material.

With the weaknesses of this course, what was really difficult was that, with the lectures, there seemed to just be this level of expectation that students should either already know a lot of the background and be able to know and do most of the things already or should be able to learn it all on their own and that the class was more about filling in the details with the nuances or the rigorous mathematical concepts behind the big-picture, higher-level ideas. However, I think that for me and some of the students, this class was the first serious statistics class we had, which made the level of this class really high. For students like us, the overall goals of the various concepts then were never spelled out; they just seemed to be assumed as things we would know or be able to easily pick up, so lecture ended up being extremely hard to follow. I felt like this class seemed more like a class for graduate students, but allowing undergraduate students to sit in, rather than a class that is a core requirement for the undergraduate major. I guess it makes sense, since the undergraduate program is relatively new, but it would be really nice for there to be some restructuring so that the class is more approachable for undergraduates. There definitely isn't a sense that this is an introductory class for the major. I guess, right now, the expectations are very high for this course, at least with the lectures, and it almost makes it feel exclusive like a weed-out class instead of open for students who want to learn, but who lack the exposure or background. It would just be wonderful if it could be made more approachable, at least with going more slowly with explaining some of the basics of statistics, explaining the big picture, and explaining how things fit together. I think, right now, the focus in the class really was in the nitty-gritty details, the nuances, and the math, but then, it would be difficult to go back and make the connections back to the overall idea. 

Having more opportunities to receive help would be great. This might just be a suggestion for statistics classes and the whole department in general. Right now, I think the CS department does an incredible job with offering help and how they organize office hours and ULAs/TFs so that students can get help every day of the week. If there was a way to imitate that with the statistics department, that would be so incredible. It would really help students who want to put in the time and effort to understand the material.

The biggest strength of this course is how relatable it is to other statistics classes. However, some of the material doesn't seem overly important to know given the age of complicated statistical software that we live in. In addition, the material covered in class was often not in the book, which is great, except that all of the homework was from the textbook, so we were forced to learn from that as well.

I thought the course was well taught and had a lot of resources available. Section was extremely helpful. However, the ULA's office hours were scheduled at extremely inconvenient times when virtually no one could attend which was frustrating.

The first half of the course was alright, up until after MLEs. After that, the lectures stopped making any sense really. Professor Barron presented the material in a very roundabout and disorganized way. He spent a lot of time being pedantic about details like whether the null hypothesis should be on top in the likelihood ratio, without ever clearly presenting what the likelihood ratio was, or when you would use it. Barron is not the best lecturer and the quality really dropped off halfway through the semester, most people I know were super confused. We also started using Minitab which made things even more confusing because 1) no one uses minitab 2) he didnt bother to explain the test he was doing before he did it. 

If Prof Barron prepared organized lecture notes and could stay on topic explaining the key concepts before going into tangents the class would be a lot better.

I really liked the content of the course. Toward the end, some of the regression topics seemed a bit repetitive. For example, we would do some derivations twice and while doing new derivations in between - if you hadn't reviewed the lecture notes, it was then hard to distinguish between what was new and what wasn't. On the whole though, this was a great course. I felt like the amount of homework was just right - it forced me to learn the material but didn't take up my entire week.

Strengths: Professor Baron's sense of humor and openness to answering questions and helping his students.   Weaknesses: I wasn't a huge fan of the textbook, and lectures sometimes felt a bit disorganized.

The structure of the course grade-wise and assignment-wise is fine, but the lectures and exams are way too specific. I felt as if I never grasped a true understanding of statistical theory before I have to use some specific application of it.

I thought that the psets and exams were fair. The lectures are much more theory based than either the problem sets or exams and can be very hard to follow. The textbook does not always go into theory either so the main source of theoretical understanding was the lectures, which is bad if you do not learn well in lectures.
If you are an S&DS major then yes.

In hindsight I wish I'd taken a different course to fulfill the same requirement. I found Prof. Barron's teaching style to be abrasive and disorienting, sometimes similar to the book and others entirely different. The 2 midterms were both pretty fair and the homeworks are difficult but doable. Just wished I'd gotten more out of the time I spent in class.

Yes, the course material is important for further studies of statistics, but expect to do a lot of self-studying apart from lecture because going to lecture really isn't that helpful. The professor goes off tangents and tests on various things that he didn't teach in lecture or the review session.

I would recommend this course to another student if and only if they have an interest in statistics beyond its application, meaning if a student wants to understand why a t-test works and why we can analyze p-values, then they would be a great candidate to take this course. This course is fairly dull if you do not enjoy the thrill of statistics and the beauty of the math behind it, although we glossed over all the cool mathematical phenomenons that make stats possible.
If you like stats this class is a must. Can be dry at times but sets you up with very strong foundation.

I'd say take it only if you have to, and if you do, make sure you go for lectures. It may seem at first like they are useless, but they are helpful. Professor Barron does not put up lecture slides, so instead of having to read through entire chapters in the textbook and trying to figure out what to read and what not to read on your own, just go for class. Take this from someone who didn't attend class for the first half of semester then did so for the second half and noticed the incredible difference.
On another note, skim through the textbook before lecture - it will help.

If you're in S&DS you pretty much have to take it. If you're applied math I would still recommend it. It is not too challenging and although at times it can be a bit slow, a lot of the information is very interesting and you can see what is behind a lot of the things we often take for granted in statistics.
If you can avoid this class, do.

I would recommend this course to another student who wants to explore more of the theory of statistics. If students are looking more for an introduction to statistics or direct practical application, they should probably take a different class.

I would recommend this course to anyone who needs to take it. If you do not have to, take something else. Also, make sure you know R/Matlab/Minitab. The material is good but suffering through the lectures makes this a hard class to take for fun. Perhaps just read the textbook if interested in the subject matter? It is as if this was a linear algebra class that does not know whether it is 225 or 222.

I would not recommend the course. It seems there are better statistics options. This one is kind of poorly organized and taught. But if it's required, pay full attention in class and you will learn something. You can definitely get a lot out of it.
Needed for stats major, background knowledge is useful.
Overall, I feel neutral about this course. The S&DS requires it for a B.S., however, so I guess in that case you don't really have a choice.
Yes, it is necessary if you want to do anything related to data.
No, very poorly taught. No engaging lectures, and PSETs on material we learn after due date of psets.

I've been thinking about this question for a long time and literally still have no idea. If you're dead set on doing the S&DS BS, you might want to just bite the bullet and tough it out on this one, like I did. If you're not, you might be better off taking another S&DS course and then coming back to 242 later on in your Yale career, at which point you'll have more background anyways. This course is flat out terrible and really not worth taking for the content you learn, so literally the only benefit is doing it for the BS. The second half, hypothesis testing, is covered entirely in other S&DS courses at Yale, and the first half, parameter estimation (maximum likelihood, method of moments, Delta method, Bayesian) is stuff you could probably learn independently.

Only take this class if you absolutely need to - there are a lot of other statistics classes that are more engaging and would teach you similar concepts. Having said that, if you are able to self-study very well, the class is pretty managable.
Only really if you have to take it... workload is large

With reservations. It's not interesting enough to take it for itself; it should be a bridge to another class or to something practical. If I look back, I do feel like I gained skills that could be really helpful in research, but also that I only  understood or  internalized what we were doing and I'm afraid I'll have forgotten a lot of it by the end of the summer.

I was extremely worried before taking this course because of the previous reviews, but let me tell you: it is not as bad as people say it is ! Ok, maybe the textbook is not the best and Professor Barron is not the most organized lecturer but I could tell he was making efforts. Also, he is extremely passionate about his subject and genuinely wants students to understand the concepts. The TFs were super helpful too (Molly & Dylan) - go to their discussion section for help with homework. If you put in the effort, you will learn and the tests are faire so you can definitely do well. This is not a "trick" class. You just have to stay engaged with the material and it will pay off.
Not really

Overall a solid course. I walked out feeling like I had a workable grasp of the concepts and that I could apply them to a variety of situations. Definitely try to take it with a few friends, or find some pset buddies in the class. That was a huge help and made a world of a difference throughout the semester and in studying for exams. The exams themselves are very fair, and you're allowed to bring in a cheat sheet which is great. Homework is weighted 40% which may seem like a lot, but was a nice buffer in case the exams didn't go as well as you'd hoped. Definitely read the textbook. Barron's lectures can be a bit meandering and not super clear, but the textbook, while dry, helps get the main concepts. The peer tutor office hours were also a hidden gem so take advantage of those for sure.

this class is not well taught. Don't take it if you don't absolutely have to. Homework can sometimes be super tedious and frustrating. If you absolutely need to take it for your major  really no need in going to lectures but absolutely critical to find a study group.

You should take this course if you have a basic background in probability theory. If you're majoring in STEM or a quantitative social science, you really ought to take this over the 100 level courses.

Excellent course. Barron is a very clear lecturer who draws connections and moves at a good pace. The textbook is wonderful and the selected problems really solidify intuitions. The work given is appropriately challenging and enough to really make you learn it. Great overall course design.
No, unless required. Was a terrible introduction to stat and Barron is not great.

If you have to, take it. 

If you dont have to but want to know what happens when you type, say, t.test() in R, like me, you should take it too. 

Otherwise, dont take it.

If you are studying anything that requires statistic testing, then I highly recommend this course (particularly in conjunction with a more applicative class like S&DS 230) to understand the theory of statistic testing and how to use them.
Do not take this class if it is not required. While the material is interesting, it is horribly taught and it's really unclear what is being taught at any given time due to the terrible organization.

The material taught in this course is very important for understanding statistics, and its not at all a repeat of AP Stat. But there is a hard problem set every week, and to learn the material to do the problem set you need to go to class (not helpful, since lecture is very confusing and often veers off into more advanced material), read the textbook (sometimes helpful since the problems are from there, but not too good), or go to the optional section with the TAs (quite helpful). This combination of hard problem sets + no good way to learn the material unless you can make the sections makes the class really time-consuming and frustrating. I didnt enjoy the course, and it could have been taught much better, but I am at least happy I (sort of) learned the material. I only recommend it if you really want a class to teach you this material.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because, even after all of the difficulties of the class, you leave the class with a much better grasp of statistics and what it entails. I feel so much more ready to move forward with statistics having taken this class, and I really enjoyed this class overall. I thought the material was extremely interesting. I think you just have to understand that to get to the point of understanding it, there will be difficulties because this class is difficult and challenging, but definitely worth it. You can do it!
Only take this if you have to for a major.
I would definitely recommend this course, I think its super important info to know. The course is pretty well taught and definitely manageable.

Depends  if you want to go to grad school for stats / math, then you should definitely take this course. If youre looking to learn how to use statistical tests on data and practice with R or something, then this class probably isnt for you. 

Its not exceptional, but not awful. The material covered is relevant for future statistics courses, and at times the mathematical theory behind it made sense. The class mostly gave me a way of thinking statistically, and key paradigms like finding maximum likelihood and testing hypothesis at a significance level. It started making sense the final review session, when Prof. Barron actually explained how these frameworks influence a lot of statistical tests, before everything was super confusing. Prof. Barron definitely understands statistics well but doesnt seem to understand/care too much whether students are really learning. I mostly learned from the book and after MLEs the lectures were generally disorganized and not wroth going to.

Yes, I would totally recommend this course! This is the first statistics course that has made me feel like I truly understand statistics and probability theory. It is really cool to know the mathematical background between the different hypothesis tests (e.g. chi-squared test, t-test, z-test) and how they are different. This course can be a lot of work at times, but it is definitely one of the more eye-opening classes I have taken at Yale. Take this class!

I'd recommend this course if you're studying anything related to statistics I found it rewarding to understand the theoretical foundations of things like regression and parameter estimation that seem to be taken for granted in more higher level or practical stats classes. The class does take some work I found it pretty important to read the textbook to do the homework problems since the lectures didn't cover everything that the problems asked, and it also always took some time after class to decipher my notes from lecture and understand what was going on (Professor Baron is kind and willing to help his students, but his lectures are sometimes disorganized and a little hard to follow). In the end though, it was a pretty rewarding class.

Only take if you have to. The lectures are only helpful for the exams and the exam questions are pretty specific. Did not feel like I had a good understanding of the general theory of statistics. Workload is fine, about five hours a week for me.

Most of the people who take 242 need it for their major. However, if you will use statistics in your work (the sciences and social sciences for example) you should consider taking 242 over the statistics course offered by your department because you will understand the mathematical foundations of statistics much better instead of viewing statistics formulaically. Also, if you took 238 instead of 241, I would highly recommend reading a lot of probability theory before taking the course (though taking 241 first would be ideal).
